Bitburner is a hacking and cyberpunk themed idle game that's completely unique in that it has an embedded programming language (using the JavaScript engine) that you can use in-game for various idle-game tasks. In it, you make money via simulated hacking of servers (not using any real-world hacking techniques, so don't worry, it's not THAT hard), and later, various other techniques, such as gaming the stock market, working a crime system, or completing coding contracts. This might be a bit difficult for people who are not programming nerds, but boy oh boy, does this game go deep, and it's a lot of fun.

This idle game is completely unique in that it has me automating the playing of the game at basically all times I have it running idle. There's always some system to optimize, or something to refactor. It has an uncanny way of eating up all my time despite it being an idle game! The systems at play are never trivial to get right, either, even if you know how to code. The game gradually introduces new systems, too, making for a smooth (if a little slow in the beginning) progression curve.

I guess the only flaw is that sometimes it can ask a lot of you. Like, I am a professional software engineer of many years with a postgraduate degree in computer science and in the later-game, Bitburner makes me scratch my head sometimes as to how to reasonably do something well. A lot of my solutions aren't optimal (yet), and some optimal solutions I feel like I need to read academic papers to do best. A select few things are truly tasks people a thousand times better than me have put a thousand more times of work into, and still have not perfected it. Madness.

Do I recommend this if you just want to jump in to learning how to program? I don't know. The game will go slower for you than others, and the game isn't fast to begin with. And don't get me started on using other people's scripts. That's cheating! But I mean, this is a free game that will never ask for money, and open-source to boot, so you might as well give it a try. It's a lot of fun and has me hooked.

Installed this to learn how to program. Have barely started learning proper and already having fun playing the game. Looking forward to understanding the code of the game itself next once I figure out Github!

It's a game with actual programming baked into the gameplay loop. Found myself enjoying it enough to want to rate it highly, which is not usual of coding games, for me. Really enjoyable, once you get a few good scripts under your belt.

The game uses actual JavaScript, which can be a fun learning tool or just a means of keeping yourself sharp. It uses something called the "NetScript" API to interact with the game itself so no actual hacking, unless you want all the achievements(then some real "hacking").

I can't recommend this game enough. Like all the other reviews say, if you find yourself here, play it.

Bitburner redefines incremental gaming by plunging players into a cyberpunk dystopia where hacking corporations and amassing trillions hinges on writing real JavaScript scripts, transforming idle progression into a hands-on coding playground that rewards logic over clicks. Launched in 2021 and thriving on Steam with steady updates through 2025, the game casts you as a terminal operative infiltrating networks, joining factions for augmentations that trigger prestige resets, and automating everything from money laundering to gang warfare via Netscript—a JavaScript dialect with game-specific APIs for scanning servers, deploying worms, and optimizing hack/grow/weaken ratios

First and foremost, this is a programming game. It is going to be basically impossible to play without programming knowledge. It uses Javascript or Typescript depending on your preference. I don't know if the internal text editor supports TS, but it's much better to use an external one anyway.  It has its own custom APIs, but otherwise it runs in a browser and every browser Javascript API is available to use/abuse. (Check out Viteburner for automated script synchronization)

Other than programming, the game has the typical incremental game loop. Progress/buy upgrades/reset.

I started this game for the first time almost two years ago when I was on vacation. I write software professionally, and I usually enjoy it. I just don't often want to write code after doing it all day at work. So I often start a small project that I can do in a week when I'm on vacation.

Well, that vacation I chose to play Bitburner, and it's great. It's probably the best programming game out there, and it's not even close. I honestly wish they charged a few bucks here, because it's worth it. I'll have to see if they have a donation/charity where I can contribute a few bucks.

Recently, I purchased another programming game involving a farm. It's not bad, but it just made me think I should come back and see about finishing Bitburner.

It's taken me several hours to somewhat re-familiarize myself and figure out the (of course insufficiently documented) code I wrote so long ago, but I've actually made some progress. I [i]was[/i] shocked that the code wasn't nearly as bad/messy I was expecting it to be, so documenting it wasn't that bad. Good job, old me.

Anyway, fundamentally the game is about hacking and writing automation in Javascript to automatically do things for you. At the start, this is hacking a few machines to make some cash. As you progress, however, other gameplay features come up. This includes things like a stock market, employment, real life crime, etc. There's even a Go game which I've yet to even attempt to make a smart AI. I'll take the abysmal win percentage of random placement before trying to write a Go algorithm. As new features are unlocked, that means more things to automate. Even going as far as automating things you do in the physical world.

The automation can be as simple or complex as you want, really. I ended up writing a scheduler that distributes running programs across my network of hacked machines. Did I need to do that? Nope. And in hindsight, it probably wasn't worth the effort, but the code is still solid today and makes tons of money and allows me to essentially have a single giant pool of resources to run every script I've written. I just send a script/args to the scheduler and it figures out which machine has the resources to run it.

This game just runs in a browser, so if you want to be a real sneaky hacker you can even manipulate the DOM and do stuff that normally requires an upgrade. It's actually not a bug. It's allowed, but requires significant (in game) system resources.

I highly recommend Bitburner if you're looking for a programming game, and especially if you like the idle/incremental game loop. Some of the tasks can be pretty complex, so it's likely best to have at least some professional experience, but a CS student could absolutely learn a lot here as well with the right amount of stubbornness.

Bitburner is a unique game that invites you to write scripts in a JavaScript-style language (Netscript) to automate your hacking, build systems, and progress through a cyberpunk world of servers and factions. It combines incremental game mechanics with strategic scripting and automation.

What Makes It Great

It makes you think—you decide which servers to hack, how to script growth or weaken loops, and how to scale your operations.

The scripting is flexible and accessible: even players with little programming experience can follow tutorials and use community code to get started.

It’s a sandbox: you’re free to choose your path—hacking networks, joining factions, automating buy/upgrade loops, taking on special missions.

There’s a satisfying progression: from basic scripts and a handful of servers to whole networks, optimized routines, and advanced automation.

A vibrant community shares scripts, guides and tools across GitHub and Steam, helping both novices and veterans alike.

Why It Works

Bitburner respects your time: you can work on your scripts, walk away, and your operations still generate progress (especially at the grow/weaken level). It rewards creativity rather than forcing a rigid path. That said, there is a learning curve—documentation exists, but you’ll benefit from exploring and experimenting rather than relying on heavy guidance.

Final Thoughts

If you enjoy solving problems, writing or tweaking code, or building efficient systems, Bitburner is an outstanding choice. It blends hacking-themed aesthetics with real scripting and automation depth.
5/5 – A smart, empowering, and endlessly modifiable experience.

Hello there,

I recently discovered this beautiful coding game named Bitburner.

An incremental game where you make thousands, millions, billions, and so on bucks to access game systems that allow you to make even more of afforementioned currency units.

It uses real javascript, a horrible, horrible abomination of a programming language, as any true programmer can tell you.

Though, during my journey throug the Bitnodes I started to realize, that it has this in common with most other programming languages. So I was able to lay down a few of my fundamentalist prejudices against it.

Don't get me wrong, it's still a horrible language. But the number of people telling you this about a programming language is a hallmark of its success. What you are hearing are the tortured voices of the many poor souls who have to earn a living with this abominations. Cold machines of logic. Implementing the coffee fueled fever dreams of delusional people. Until those people can afford cocaine.. then it really gets interesting.

But wait.. I'm starting to babble again..

I'm safe here. This is a game. The business people can't hurt me.


So.. where was I... yes, for the first time since about 10 years I had fun coding again. Imagine that. So I decided to give a warm recommendation for this game.

I have to say, this game is getting dangerously close to what I did in my dayjob as a sofware developer. Not only in the sense of getting screwed over by the small shortcuts I take, really. But simply the fact that most of the things I'm doing is pulling data from somewhere by combing documentation, reformat it and/or do some calculations with it to then shove the data elsewhere. So familiar.

Of course the devil is in the details and "reformat" and "do some calculations" is easily said. And those few harmless seeming words contain a world of horror and harebrained schemes.


Playing this really can make you understand what is meant with "scalability" in software development. You start with scarce resources, reach a level of plenty but will be reset to a period of scarcity again before you can progress the game.
This causes many interesting problems regarding scalability for your scripts.

Has Bitburner inspired an army of faux black hats? Not real hackers (probably), but thousands of pajama-clad cyberlords feeling like Mr. Robot while actually learning JavaScript basics. You start small — poking at low-security servers, writing baby scripts to siphon virtual cash, and watching your “hack” bar inch across the screen — but before long you’re building sprawling networks of automated scripts, daisy-chaining backdoors, and cornering the digital stock market while your real-world coffee goes cold. The game’s biggest crime? Making file I/O, network penetration, and RAM allocation look cooler than anything on Netflix.

Every milestone feels like leveling up your hacker alter ego: buying more servers, scaling scripts for maximum efficiency, and setting up intricate cron-job style loops that run while you sleep. Bitburner doesn’t just simulate hacking; it sneaks in a coding boot camp disguised as an idle game. At 2 a.m., bleary-eyed and triumphant, you’ll realize you’ve turned into the very villain your antivirus warned you about—only instead of stealing real money, you’re optimizing loops and balancing thread counts. It’s hilarious, it’s dangerously educational, and it’s the most fun you can have “hacking” without ending up on a watchlist.

Bitburner is a really cool game in which you write scripts to automate the process of hacking fictional corporations. As you might expect, at least basic experience with coding is very helpful here as it very much mirrors actually coding in most ways, but that experience also means the world is your oyster, and the real fun of the game is making your own working script and watching your hard work pay off. If you're scared about getting lost with this much freedom, fret not, there is also well put together documentation in game if you need an early-game walkthrough, explanation on mechanics, or just a refresher. Plus, programmers will feel right at home flipping between it and the terminal or your scripts, given the frequent visits to Stack Overflow. The gameplay loop is also soundly made, mixing coding with automation downtime that can happen even when you close the game. The interface is friendly and simple, allowing you to focus on what's important. And maybe best of all is it really sells itself on the theming and concept. Beyond aesthetic choices that mimic the common style of hacker memes, the gameplay is truly in the spirit of hacking and coding, and nothing demonstrates that better than the fact you can simply hack in all of the achievements. Sure it'd be cheating anywhere else, but that perfectly aligns with what a game about hacking should be about, and I think that's awesome.

I love the style of this game. It's very fun if you're interested in this kind of stuff. Although it isn't directly applicable IRL, it holds a great set of lessons that—mostly you, yourself—will have to discover through gameplay.
pretty neat game, u gotta search stuff up unless ur java knowledge is lvl entrpeneure

As someone that has completely zero knowledge of coding, it is a fun introduction.
gg. much easier if you plan all the scripts out from the start and have a manager script going. don't underestimate the power of farming n00dles. awesome scripting game

A very simple and straightforward idle clicker game that allows you to write JavaScript files using a custom module that the game provides (called ns2). You run those scripts on pretend computers which are upgraded using in-game dollar. It is less story-focused than a game like Hacknet, and is instead more focused on exploring its different mechanics. Over time, you gain access to better nodes, better money sources, better features and stat upgrades. There is a critical mechanic called 'augmentations'. These are insanely expensive to buy in bulk, and require the player to invest a lot of time, as they can only be installed upon 'rebirths'. You will eventually hit a wall if you try to play without these, which is a bit annoying. Solid game to mess around with for like 10 minutes and then run in the background for 10 hours. Terrible game if you want actual entertainment. But at least you get the happy chemicals when big number goes bigger, right?

If you want that classic movie trope "i'm in" feeling this is the game for you. It's a good way to keep my javascript sharp and also for just understanding how code works. I would recommend having an introductory level of knowledge about JS before diving in maybe, but definitely use this to help you learn while you also have a little fun.

Genuinely fantastic game. it allows full freedom after the tutorial for programming and you can really do whatever you want. story is a little dry (because there is none) for the first 30 minutes or so, but once you level up and get going, its a blast. 

Dont feel discouraged if you dont know javascript. My recommendation is try to follow along with super super basic stuff like ns.hack("name") and basic programs like that until you start getting the hang of it. Its a great project game so instead of watching 3 hour long tutorials for javascript, you can actually write things like youre using a real framework.

Great for programmers, fun game with tons of things to do, requires real skill to optimize and preform tasks, cute little side segments and fun concepts executed really well, I strongly recommend this for people big into Hacknet, people into basic Java, or people just looking to try something new.

(I have to specify, I played thee webgl version of the game for a few hours about a year ago now, I'm not new to this lol)

100%’d the entire game in under an hour. Not a typo - one hour. The devs clearly designed this for people who still need tooltips to open doors. I came, I saw, I broke the balance. Every server melted faster than my GPU fan at full load. I didn’t even try to speedrun, it just kind of happened because efficiency is in my blood.

I reverse-engineered the mechanics mid-game optimized the RNG, and accidentally found three exploits while alt-tabbing to check Discord. The devs should honestly add a new difficulty level called “Me.” Until then, I’ll be waiting for DLC worthy of my skillset.

10/10, but only because I can’t rate it 11/10 and write my own patch notes.

If you ended up here, do yourself a favour and download it.

As for the automation aspect, it's kinda like factorio on crack, with all the right pop-culture references and actual scripting.

Best 0$ I have ever spent.

This game is about automation.
The game doesn't have a story for the first ~75 hours of gameplay WITH background programming knowledge.
[b] I recommend Hacknet. [/b] I thought this game would be a similar story/puzzle game.
It feels like a second job. There is a lot to explore, but it doesn't feel rewarding. It feels like I wasted hours programming for just a Steam achievement!
This game is good for the first ~35-50 hours, it just gets boring over time. It's just too long.
This game will not shut off and has no option to uninstall. Stay far away.

I really love the old MS-DOS graphics of this game. In fact, I made a similar game (never released it) years ago, and I was going to give it a positive review when I first started playing this game, but the game feels like a job for me, and I don't like when games either unnecessarily complex or feel like job (you have to explore too many things just to be able to play). The only exception to this rule might be Dota 2, which is too deep and you have to explore and research it, if you miss 1 year of playing and return to the game, you will feel like you launched totally new game, but Dota 2 at least feels rewarding and there are tons of content to look forward and progresses to make, so it is a never ending grind. But this game? It is literally just a Command Prompt simulator which doesn't even make you feel rewarded for doing things, you are just doing your usual coding. If I wanted to just code, I would code and make money by doing it, which again makes this game a waste of my time, in my honest opinion.

I really wanted to play this but in the tutorial they had me copy and paste a code that didn't even work and the game says... congratulations your first code is working, when it clearly says in the terminal in red letters that it is not. How does the game let you go past a tutorial that didn't show me what to do?

Not sure the audience for this game. You essentially need to already know how to code Javascript to play the game. Sure there are in game "guides" but it is essentially an entire wiki you need to read on how to use Javascript to play the game. And what little "tutorial" that exists isn't great in how it explains and guides things. I actually got stuck in the tutorial for a bit because it told me to "press the button" without clearly identifying the button it was talking about. There is no learning curve, it is a learning wall. If you don't know how to code, you can't play this game. If you do know how to code, I don't know why this game would be interesting. Cool project i guess?
There's a syntax error in the first piece of code it tells you to copy and paste into the tutorial.

I made one script at the very beginning after reading the markdown docs on github and then walked away for a bit to go touch grass. I came back to a TON of cringe popup messages layered on top of each other (that I had to close out one by one) that talked about how I'm "digging too deep" or how some guy liked the cut of my jib or whatever. I had a lot of notifications and I felt like I missed everything while the game progressed the story without me. I was expecting this game to be an idle game based on how it was tagged. I wouldn't really call typing up scripts and typing a lot in general being idle.

The RAM system sucks. Why would it take a GB of RAM on my home computer to run a script on someone else's computer? The script being executed isn't being ran on my home computer too. The multitasking system sucks too. The character levelling system is jarring next to the hacker-man gameplay with a working built-in IDE.

I had way more fun making a js file that plays fart sounds at random intervals as long as the browser tab it's running in stays open.

I dunno, maybe this game is fun if you like pretending to be a hacker or somethin'. Boring coding game, terrible idle game. Would be an alright text-based RPG but the writing throughout the game is... something else.

I actually got stuck in the tutorial for a bit because it told me to "press the button" without clearly identifying the button it was talking about. There is no learning curve, it is a learning wall. If you don't know how to code, you can't play this game. If you do know how to code, I don't know why this game would be interesting. Cool project i guess?
There's a syntax error in the first piece of code it tells you to copy and paste into the tutorial.

I made one script at the very beginning after reading the markdown docs on github and then walked away for a bit to go touch grass. I came back to a TON of cringe popup messages layered on top of each other (that I had to close out one by one) that talked about how I'm "digging too deep" or how some guy liked the cut of my jib or whatever. I had a lot of notifications and I felt like I missed everything while the game progressed the story without me. I was expecting this game to be an idle game based on how it was tagged. I wouldn't really call typing up scripts and typing a lot in general being idle.

The RAM system sucks. Why would it take a GB of RAM on my home computer to run a script on someone else's computer? The script being executed isn't being ran on my home computer too. The multitasking system sucks too. The character levelling system is jarring next to the hacker-man gameplay with a working built-in IDE.

I had way more fun making a js file that plays fart sounds at random intervals as long as the browser tab it's running in stays open.

I dunno, maybe this game is fun if you like pretending to be a hacker or somethin'. Boring coding game, terrible idle game. Would be an alright text-based RPG but the writing throughout the game is... something else.
